{"metadata":{"objective":"Balancing your ideas and those of others","lastStepAudioPath":"summary"},"steps":[{"headerText":"Balancing your ideas and those of others","leftText":"<p><span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\"><strong>You are</strong></span>&nbsp;writing a brief history of your family to accompany a speech you are giving at a family reunion.&nbsp;<br /><br />You have lots of information from research that you have done and from stories that your family members have provided.&nbsp; You also have plenty of your own ideas!<br /><br /><span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\"><strong>You want to learn</strong></span> how to put them all together so that your research provides effective support for what you want to say, and your own ideas come across loud and clear.<br /><br /><span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\"><strong>Try it!</strong></span></p><p><br /><span class=\"ju-small-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:14px;\">Note:&nbsp; All family history sources used here are fictional.</span><br /><br /><span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\"><span style=\"color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial; white-space: pre-wrap;\">Note for screen readers: Press Alt + 1 , or option + 1 on Mac, to open the try it information box in a new window and access information needed to answer some of the questions. In the content, this needed information is described as being in the box or table to the right.</span></span></p>","rightText":"<p><img alt=\"An illustration shows that you want to balance your ideas with the words and ideas of others from your research and the stories your family members have told you.\" src=\"data:image/png;base64,\" /></p>","settings":{"showHeader":1,"showAudio":1,"audioPath":"","hideRightPanel":0,"showNext":1,"delayStep":"0","delayRight":"0","showRFB":0}},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>Your writing consists mostly of your own words and ideas, but you need to support your ideas with the words and ideas of others.<br /><br />You can present information from other sources using <strong>direct quotations</strong>, <strong>paraphrasing</strong>, or <strong>summarizing</strong>.<br /><br />You decide which of those techniques to use based upon what you are trying to tell your readers.<br />&nbsp;</p><table cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-table\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><thead><tr><th scope=\"col\"><strong>Use. . .</strong></th><th scope=\"col\"><strong>When you. . .</strong></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Direct quotations</td><td>want your reader to view the exact words from your source.</td></tr><tr><td>Paraphrasing</td><td>want to present the main points and all the details using your own words.</td></tr><tr><td>Summarizing</td><td>have lots of information and want to include only the main points.&nbsp;</td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Integrating sources into your writing"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>Fill in the blanks in the following statements.<br /><br />1.&nbsp; Your writing should synthesize the material you have learned.<br /><br />Simply including multiple quotations, summaries, or paraphrases from other sources does not show your reader enough original thinking.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Balancing the words and ideas of others with your own ideas"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":0,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"fullWhiteboard":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>What is the key problem with this paragraph?</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><span class=\"ju-double-space\" style=\"line-height: 180%;\">Grandpa Patrick Walsh told many stories that describe the details of a firefighter&#39;s life.&nbsp; One memory he shared was of fighting fires with a fire engine drawn by a team of horses (Jones, 2014).&nbsp; &ldquo;A fire horse was a dedicated creature, and it was always a sad event in any company when a veteran steed was forced to retire&rdquo; (West, 2011, p. 131). &nbsp;&nbsp;A firefighter in New York City in the 1920s spent nine of 10 days on the job.&nbsp; Day number 10 was for catching up with family, friends, and neighbors (West, 2011).&nbsp; &ldquo;Firefighters were often inspired to follow this career based on their own personal experiences&rdquo; (Jones, 2014, p. 37).&nbsp; In the 1920s, fires were both common and devastating in big cities. (West, 2011).</span></p></td></tr></tbody></table>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_806a9486-8112-0722-bdd8-0f3aaeffacb1\" style=\"width: 200px; height: 20px;\" /><span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">Screen reader version of Balancing your ideas and your sources, opens in a new tab</span></a><br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>Your reader needs to know when your ideas begin and end and what words and ideas are borrowed from others.<br /><br />One way you can do this is by using a <strong>signal phrase </strong>such as <em>According to West</em> or <em>As Kellen West explains</em> with the date in parentheses after the source&#39;s name.<em>&nbsp; </em>Using a signal phrase is considered citing.&nbsp; It lets the reader know the author of your source.<br /><br />&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <img alt=\"For example, you start a paragraph with your own ideas.  At the end of your own ideas, you start the next sentence with the signal phrase As Kellen West (2011) explains, and follow this with words and ideas of Kellen West that support your points.\" src=\"data:image/png;base64,\" /></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>If your signal phrase introduces a <strong>direct quotation</strong>, also include the page or paragraph number after the direct quotation and before the period:<br />&nbsp;</p><p style=\"margin-left: 40px;\"><span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\">According to Kellen West (2011), &quot;a fire horse was a dedicated creature&quot; <span class=\"marker\">(p. 131)</span>.</span><br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><br /><br />&nbsp;</p>","headerText":"Using signal phrases"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":0,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>Which signal phrase in this paragraph from your family history indicates that ideas are borrowed from another source?</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><span class=\"ju-double-space\" style=\"line-height: 180%;\">Many of you remember when I asked Uncle Hiram for help to control an invasion of ants at our lake house.&nbsp; Hiram told me to purchase a package of thick sidewalk chalk and meet him at the lake.&nbsp; When we got there, he took the chalk and drew several heavy lines across the bottom of the driveway.&nbsp; As I watched, I saw ants divert their path and head away from the house.&nbsp; They would not cross that chalk line.&nbsp; Uncle Hiram was right!&nbsp; Ants can be controlled by drawing a chalk line! As Edgar Smith (2012) explains in his book, <em>Pesky Pests,</em> &quot;When ants are on the move, they create a pheromone trail for other ants to follow.&nbsp; Drawing the chalk line breaks up the pheromones, dispersing the army of ants from their march&quot; (p. 21).</span></p></td></tr></tbody></table>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_ab9cafe0-edc9-1d46-315c-828295ee2e87\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\">MC Placeholder<br /><strong>ID: mc_6bd7...</strong></jumc><span>&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>If you do not choose to use a signal phrase, you include a citation with the author&#39;s name at the end of the direct quotation, paraphrase, or summary:</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><span class=\"ju-normal\" style=\"color:black;font-family:lato,sans-serif;font-size:16px;\"><span class=\"ju-double-space\" style=\"line-height: 180%;\">. . .&nbsp; Uncle Hiram was right!&nbsp; Ants can be controlled by drawing a chalk line!&nbsp; &quot;When ants are on the move, they create a pheromone trail for other ants to follow.&nbsp; Drawing the chalk line breaks up the pheromones, dispersing the army of ants from their march&quot; <span class=\"marker\">(Smith, 2012, p. 21)</span>.</span></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>Is it better to cite your source using the&nbsp;author&#39;s name in a signal phrase or with an in-text citation?&nbsp;<br /><br />The choice is yours.<br /><br />Good writers vary their style to keep readers&#39; interest.&nbsp; Try reading your work aloud and experimenting with both ways of acknowledging the author or source.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>If you use many pieces of information from the same source within one paragraph, acknowledge the source <strong>each time</strong> you include a direct quotation, paraphrase, or summary in the paragraph.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Citing the same source more than once in a paragraph"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>This paragraph from your family history includes information that comes from a book by John Andrews, published in 2016.<br /><br />It includes two paraphrases and a direct quotation, all from Andrews&#39;s book.&nbsp; Indicate whether each sentence requires a citation.</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p style=\"line-height:250%;\">The young men who served the Pony Express never submitted a written application or were interviewed for the job; they simply showed up, shook hands, and were hired on the spot&nbsp;<jumc ju-mc=\"mc_cbd4bc9d-3cb8-97ae-c233-11052b501b98\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\"><strong>ID: mc_cbd4...</strong></jumc>. In fact, it was not uncommon for several members of the same family to arrive at the station looking for work; generally, all were hired <jumc ju-mc=\"mc_819615cb-4e3e-5c4f-d369-8ecbbeb7e826\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\"><strong>ID: mc_8196...</strong></jumc>. &quot;During the first year of the Pony Express, riders were brought on at the rate of a hundred hires a week&quot; <jumc ju-mc=\"mc_e068b7d5-6f32-ffd0-834e-18072ab9b229\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\"><strong>ID: mc_e068...</strong></jumc>.&nbsp; When I consider how dull my own life is, I think about my Uncle Frank, the Pony Express rider, and feel a twinge of envy for him <span><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_76efad98-9ad0-0e11-9d00-7cce3aaeb1c9\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\"><strong>ID: mc_76ef...</strong></jumc></span>. &nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;<span class=\"ju-normal\" style=\"color: black; font-size: 16px;\"> </span></p></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":0,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>You can use a signal phrase to acknowledge the source each time you use it.<br /><br />If you use a signal phrase more than once, then you only need to include the date in parentheses the first time you mention the source.</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>In this paragraph, you use two ideas by John Andrews.&nbsp; Choose the best signal phrase to introduce each idea.</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><span class=\"ju-double-space\" style=\"line-height: 180%;\"><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_c9522deb-e500-06bd-2070-3536206f4fd2\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\"><strong>ID: mc_c952...</strong></jumc><span> </span></span><span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\">the riders who served as part of the Pony Express were paid very little for their services.</span></p><p><span class=\"ju-double-space\" style=\"line-height: 180%;\"><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_6d07ad67-daed-94da-2091-f9ddd793d1b3\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\"><strong>ID: mc_6d07...</strong></jumc></span><span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\"> also mentions that a typical rider rode approximately 75 miles a day before stopping to rest for the night.&nbsp;</span></p></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":""},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>This paragraph includes two direct quotations and a paraphrase, all from John Andrews&#39;s book.&nbsp; Each one is cited:<br />&nbsp;</p><ul style=\"padding-left:15px;\"><li>The first direct quotation is introduced by a signal phrase: <span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\">John Andrews (2016), author of <em>Cowboys, Cactus, and Craziness</em>, recounts. . .</span>&nbsp; This signal phrase lets your readers know that the first part of the paragraph is your own and introduces the direct quotation.&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />&nbsp;</li><li>The second direct quotation is also introduced by a signal phrase: <span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\">Andrews notes. . .</span><br />&nbsp;</li><li>The paraphrase that begins <span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\">The communication system. . .</span> is not introduced by a signal phrase, and has a citation at the end that includes the author&#39;s last name and the date.<br />&nbsp;</li></ul><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><span class=\"ju-double-space\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:lato,sans-serif;font-size:15px;line-height:180%;\">Uncle Frank&rsquo;s typical day as a Pony Express rider began before dawn.&nbsp; No matter the station where he had spent the night, an alarm would sound waking all the riders, or cowboys as they sometimes were called.&nbsp; Frank recalled&nbsp;that breakfast was served at long trestle tables and consisted of eggs, bread, and beer!&nbsp; <span class=\"marker\">John Andrews (2016)</span>,<span class=\"marker\"> author of <em>Cowboys, Cactus, and Craziness</em>, recounts</span>, &quot;Beer was served at every meal because of its long shelf life. The cowboys seemed to enjoy washing down the eggs and toast with the dark brew, some downing as many as two or three mugs of beer before setting out&quot; <span class=\"marker\">(p. 33)</span>. Immediately following breakfast, the riders rode off heading in opposite directions: as one traveled east, the other traveled west. &nbsp; <span class=\"marker\">Andrews notes</span>, &ldquo;Riders exchanged advice or warnings about the trail that they had just covered&quot; <span class=\"marker\">(p. 35)</span>.&nbsp; The communication system between riders was of key importance, providing information about weather, terrain, and other threats <span class=\"marker\">(Andrews, 2016).</span></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>If you are including information from different authors or sources, then the citation rules apply to each author or source.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Citing different sources within the same paragraph"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>This paragraph from your family history includes information from three different sources.<br />&nbsp;</p><ul style=\"padding-left:15px;\"><li>Elsa Petersen wrote a book published in 2015. She notes that a naturally aggressive plant may be very invasive when it is brought to an area that supports its growth.<br />&nbsp;</li><li>Salvatore Ricci wrote a book published in 2013. This is a direct quotation from p. 44: &quot;When the conditions are right, an introduced species will explosively take over and dominate the habitat into which it is introduced.&quot;<br />&nbsp;</li><li>&nbsp;Ellen Rivas wrote an article published in 2016. In the third paragraph, she wrote, &quot;The introduction of non-native species represents the greatest threat faced by the flora and fauna of Florida.&quot;</li></ul><p><br />Add the correct citations to the paragraph:</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p style=\"line-height:180%;\"><span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\">When a non-native plant species is introduced to a welcoming and supportive climate like that of South Florida, the species shows its ability to thrive and spread aggressively outside its native range.&nbsp; A naturally aggressive plant may be especially invasive when it is introduced to a habitat that supports growth&nbsp;</span><span class=\"ju-double-space\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:lato,sans-serif;font-size:15px;line-height:180%;\"><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_d32dafca-f0fe-07d5-41d5-e88765a9ea1b\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong>ID: mc_d32d...</strong></jumc></span><span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\">.&nbsp; Think about a plant that struggles to survive the harsh New England winters.&nbsp; Now imagine that plant transported to Florida and offered abundant sunshine, plentiful rain, and nutrient-rich soil. The plant will &ldquo;explosively take over and dominate the habitat into which it is introduced&quot; </span><span class=\"ju-double-space\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:lato,sans-serif;font-size:15px;line-height:180%;\"><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_6e675b52-3d89-2c46-1abc-e019e887de07\" style=\"width: 200px; quote a source more than once within a paragraph, acknowledge the source each time you use it with either a signal phrase or a citation in parentheses.</li><li>When you use multiple signal phrases to
